instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3437 No PM_SLP_S4_L
threads.message:
So i have a vomit damaged 3437 that came in fully dead no green light. Removed the Jtag connector, ran some wires and replaced SMC and some other small resistors. Now I have green light and PM_DSW_PWRGD but no PM_SLP_S4_L.

PPBUS_G3H - 8.6V
PP5V_S5 - 5V
PP3V3_S5 - 3.3V
PP3V3_SUS - 3.3V
PPVRTC_G3H - 3.3V
PM_DSW_PWRGD - 3.3V

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3437 No PM_SLP_S4_L
threads.message: The usual, corroded resistors in U6100 data lines, pin 8 of U1950, clock chip....Check for a pulse on L7520 right after connecting AC? Check all coils for short to GND?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3437 No PM_SLP_S4_L
threads.message: All Resistors around the Bios Chip Check and look clean, U1950 is getting its voltage and isnt fucked, Check with another clock chip off a working board and still the same problems, I am getting a quick pulse on L7520 and all coils are fine

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3437 No PM_SLP_S4_L
threads.message: Check if there are pulses on other coils too. CPU Vcore coming on shortly too?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3437 No PM_SLP_S4_L
threads.message: Yep im getting pulses of Vcore. up to right around 1.1V or so

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3437 No PM_SLP_S4_L
threads.message: All power is ok then. Still check continuity to all resistors in U6100 circuit. Check from U6100 to the 4 resistors near the CPU. Where was the corrosion?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3437 No PM_SLP_S4_L
threads.message: The Corrosion was right on top of the JTAG connector and right around the SMC area. What 4 resistors around the CPU?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3437 No PM_SLP_S4_L
threads.message: R6110-13 see page 46 and beep out all traces and resistors in the termination circuit. 16 resistors and all the traces

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3437 No PM_SLP_S4_L
threads.message: Tested all the termination circuit. Then pulled a BIOS chip from a dead board to test. We now have a working machine. Now to find a 3437 Clean ME Bios

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3437 No PM_SLP_S4_L
threads.message: Hmmm, read the original chip and use the ME region from there. ME is not corrupt probably.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3437 No PM_SLP_S4_L
threads.message: I read the original chip and stole that ME Region but the computer was back to being dead with that ME region. Put in a new ME region from here [url]http://www.win-raid.com/t596f39-Intel-Management-Engine-Drivers-Firmware-amp-System-Tools.html[/url] and everything is working fine now. Thanks again Duke. So if a machine does not see the BIOS it will do the weird power cycling?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3437 No PM_SLP_S4_L
threads.message: Also a 820-3435 SMC works fine on a 3437 Board. Just ASD thinks its an 11' air not a 13" Air.
